posts.cooked:
Hi all,

I’m interested in hearing some opinions from you guys before my team regroups to make a decision. Recently, our team went up to the North Star Regional with our robot to participate. We went up with pretty much the Kitbot, featuring tank drive and the ability to do a shallow climb. For us, we did great. Our robot was a team player for our abilities, and we had few issues with everything that happened being fixable. We made some changes to our autonomous, fixed our shallow climb being too low, and were set. Unfortunately, we didn’t place with an alliance, but we still had a great time and learned a lot. Compared to last year, our robot was pretty much a dud and unable to move on the field or even do defense, so this was an upgrade for us.

IMG_1981 1920×1280 211 KB

IMG_1981 1920×1280 211 KB

IMG_1981 1920×1280 211 KB

As our team begins to regroup following our regional, we’ve discussed trying different drive trains and seeing where that could take us. I’ve looked back on our past years, and as far as I can tell, we’ve used tank since the forming of our team, following one year where we attempted Omni and it didn’t work so we went back to tank.

I presented the idea of using a different drive train to our coach, and he seemed very interested since we have a solid team and we can make it happen. We talked about looking into swerve, and I presented an essay with some information about swerve to him and why we should take the time during our off-season to migrate. Our coach was interested, but he wants us to try doing Mecanum first before buying a swerve kit. He reasons that he wants us to work in steps up to swerve, and he claims that the mecanum will be a small step, and then we can take more time to work on swerve. Plus, it will boost our knowledge.

I’m a little worried about our time since we won’t have most of the summer to work on the robot, so I feel this might not work out for us. Personally, I wish we would take the time to migrate to swerve and learn it so then we can work on functionality during the season- I worry if we do both mecanum and swerve we will start running into interference with the season which then we won’t have time to work on functionality during the season.

I wanted to get some thoughts from you guys. Based on what you can see from the photo, and that our robot can only do a shallow climb with placing on the L1, would switching our robot to Mecanum be an upgrade from what we currently have? Navigating around the field was an issue during competition, mostly because it felt like we had to do all these weird maneuvers to make our robot do what we wanted it to do. I know that Mecanum offers more maneuverability on the field, and I feel that would help us out, but as far as lining up with the station and going back, would that be more difficult with Mecanum if we switched?

I’m hoping that in the future, we can attempt to migrate to swerve- That’s my true long-term goal. I’m absolutely in love with swerve, and I feel it would help our team at competition a lot more with the things it offers than what Tank is offering us right now. But at the moment, I’m wondering if switching to Mecanum would benefit us since that’s what my coach would like to do, and if our off-season event would go better if we used Mecanum instead of tank. And then, if all goes well, we can look into swerve and go from there.

Let me know what you guys think! I’m interested in feedback, and my team is as well. We’re all looking for ideas on how we can make this possible and make our robots’ maneuverability better for the future.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
My response to your coach would be:

“Mecanum is not a step on the way to swerve. Swerve is a completely different drivetrain, with a completely different setup. Mecanum will be “easier” to install on a kit chassis, even with the extra gearboxes required; however, swerve is rapidly becoming easier to do given the right parts. Either way, mecanum requires a completely different mechanical and programming setup than swerve does. As a matter of practicality, mecanum that isn’t driven like a swerve should really be a tank drive, and mecanum that is driven like a swerve is going to be completely outclassed by every swerve on the field.”

What I would NOT tell him is: “Some teams see mecanum and instantly remove that team from any pick lists.” Even though it’s true, it’s still not something that I think needs to be said.

One other thing:

Percentage of Swerve Drives in 2025 General Forum

I’m going to emphasize this: Rookie teams are pulling off swerve drives. You’ll find the linked thread interesting, as the data shows that swerve is currently the dominant drive style.

StarManTheGamer:

would switching our robot to Mecanum be an upgrade from what we currently have?

Downgrade. Not upgrade. Sorry. If I were you guys, I’d go for “get cheapest swerve on the market” and drive the absolute snot out of it before the offseason event.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
We spent from our Rookie year (2015) to last season as a Tank.  Towards the end…we moved from CIMs to NEOs for our drive motors.  That was quite a difference.  Changed the white wheels to black for better traction.

At the end of the school year last year…we made the switch to swerve.  We pieced the swerve system over the last few years…buying parts as we could afford them.  This year…we ran swerve for the first time.

There is a knowledge gap we needed to overcome…and we are still learning.

Bottom line:  IF you want a Corvette…never settle for Chevette.  There are a lot of swerve options out there…and coding isn’t that bad…and there is a lot of help out there if you run into problems.

I would make the leap into swerve IF I were you…you will never look back.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Doug Kavner
posts.cooked: I saw this topic and thought that someone had made a post to an open topic from 2019. Mecanum can be a fun academic exercise as part of exploring the history of drivetrains when you have nothing else to do. It’s not suitable for competition today. Get busy on an off-season swerve drive. While the basics are straight-forward, there is a lot to learn in terms of tuning, driver practice, accurate auto path following and maintenance that you don’t want to deal with in-season. We have been doing swerve for 4 years and we still find new things. Mecanum will not help you get there in any way.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
My opinion is mecanum is a dead end.

If it is at all affordable to you, I would look to the example of teams like. 9092 and 9543 (I’m sure there are others, I’m just familiar with these two). They built kit bots in their rookie year and then in year 2 essentially built kit bot (or kit bot like)  but with a swerve drivebase and saw their performance increase substantially.

Driver practice will be far more impactful in terms of performance than any drivetrain. If your driver can reach peak efficiency with your current drivetrain, you will do well. Also look into improving software to help your driver. Each of your Venoms has internal encoders, so try using them to improve autos, or make driver aids.

EricH:

mecanum that isn’t driven like a swerve should really be a tank drive, and mecanum

This is worth expanding on. When a mecanum strafes or makes any movement non perpendicular to the axis of the wheels it looses efficiency and goes slow. Sometimes, I have seen teams drive it like a tank because of this. (or gear the drivetrain wrong and it overheats when strafing). Your speed and acceleration decrease in these directions. It also means that odometry through the wheels is not possible and you would need dead wheels. Mechanum is also very sensitive to uneven mass distribution.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.cooked:
RicDV:

Rookie year (2015)…

Off topic but… What? Ah nvm I see what you meant.

Regardless:

Your point stands: a simple motor upgrade has an impact from basic CIMs. But there is some sort of detail wrong here, rev was founded in ~2014/2015 and the NEO was but a twinkle in Greg and co.'s eye in '15.

2015-2017 was the era of some wacky ( and cool ) drivetrain ideas.
Please don’t do mechanum. What someone mentioned earlier about “do not pick” lists is true.

When you are a small, underfunded team…you do what you can.

posts.name: Lauchlin
posts.cooked:
My opinion is this for current day FRC :

If a team is able to do swerve, do swerve. If they aren’t able to do swerve, do the kitbot chassis. Any other option beyond those two is a less effective option for a team and their season from a strategic design point of view.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
To the OP:

I watched your North Star matches.  I’ve been involved in the design of numerous FRC robots, have helped to start several FRC teams since 1996, and have 40+ years of motor engineering background.  Your team played well with the basic L1 design this year.  More pushing power would have given a small advantage; mecanum drive would have been a very significant disadvantage.

FTC is a great program, and mecanum drive does perform well there.  In Michigan we limit FTC to middle school teams, and many of our best FRC students progress to important roles after starting in FTC .  None of those students would recommend mecanum for an FRC robot.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
This is as comprehensive an answer as anyone could give, and I agree with all parts of it.

OP, don’t bother with Mecanum. It’s not worth the headache nowadays. I’m not convinced it was ever worth the headache.

If your center of gravity isn’t perfectly centered over the middle of the robot, you will never, ever drive straight unless you do weird stuff in your code to compensate. This makes programming a competent Mecanum drive far more difficult than it looks on the surface.

I spent 2 years mentoring 3007, a team from your neck of the woods who insisted on Mecanum year after year. We had mentors who were well-versed in wrangling Mecanum’s quirks in code. We had good habits around checking rollers for debris between matches. WE STILL NEVER DROVE STRAIGHT.

Back then, there was (sort of) a case for Mecanum. Yes it was fiddly, you never drove straight, and you always moved slower than everyone else, but you couldn’t get t-boned and tight field geometry wasn’t a hindrance. Nowadays, Swerve delivers on all all of Mecanum’s advantages, does a better job at those advantages than Mecanum can, and has none of the fiddly in-competition annoyances.

The only game I can think of where Mecanum could have had a net advantage over tank was 2015 - a game unlike any other in the RIO  era, and Mecanum STILL didn’t work great because the weight of the totes threw your CoG totally out of whack while you placed a stack. You either couldn’t drive straight while going to the feeder, or you couldn’t drive straight while placing a stack. Pick your poison.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Concurring opinion.

It is possible to have a mecanum robot that is effective and inspiring. 6167 took a mecanum Everybot to captain roles at their last two FSC events, but there are caveats:

They also were able to stay out of the way and run processor algae which was its own value add.

Having the Everybot climb was a bigger value add in FSC than the average event, in that a few of the top teams omitted any climb.

This year’s game was incrementally more mecanum-friendly, as the sprints were shorter and masked the lost power compared to, say, Crescendo or Charged Up.

This wasn’t their first time at the mecanum rodeo.

(And, well, FSC isn’t the strongest district; our top two robots are #138 and #253 in EPA , and we’ll also have #598 , #728 , and #1766 in Houston.)

Much as I bemoan the swerve tax and how the mere presence of a swerve affects a lot of teams’ pick lists now, mecanum is hustling backwards in 2025.  Barring a drastic change in rules for 2026, there are two correct answers in my eyes:

The AM14U6 chassis from the kit, on HiGrip wheels, with your preferred Toughbox Mini ratio and drivetrain motor.  Maybe the 8WD upgrade kit if you expect to burn through wheels.

COTS swerve.

The latter, implemented properly, has a much higher competitive ceiling.  But if your resources or bandwidth don’t permit doing swerve, I think the former is still a justifiable choice.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Spend all the time you’d invest making mecanum work into fundraising the money you need for a swerve drive.

With YAGSL and other code solutions for swerve sitting there ready to go the barrier to entry for a good swerve chassis is really just the money.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
evanperryg:

If your center of gravity isn’t perfectly centered over the middle of the robot, you will never, ever drive straight unless you do weird stuff in your code to compensate. This makes programming a competent Mecanum drive far more difficult than it looks on the surface.

Thank you for clarifying why mechanum is a headache instead of just saying don’t. In perfect scenarios, mechanum is pretty streamlined to get online and functional, and you hop straight to having a holonomic drive train. For this year’s Kitbot, CG is relatively solid, and it might actually make a viable mechanum bot. However, you still need to double up on gearboxes (since each wheel needs it’s own drive), on top of the wheels, so this reduces cost savings a bit.

However, CG is not the worst aspect. The moment your frame gets even slightly tweaked, you balance on two opposing wheels, losing control in both axes of motion. This is what happened to us in 2015, which was the first and last year we tried running mechanum. We just ran straight tank until 2024, well after being completely dominated by swerves, but never even seriously considered mechanum again.

For an interesting cost saving tip, you only need two swerve modules to make a swerve bot. Put them on a diagonal, and use use omni-wheels for the other corners. This is what our practice bot runs, and it works perfectly. The main snag is that most “builder” tools do actually expect 4 modules, so you kind of just ignore two of them and adjust parameters a bit. We use Yagsl, we actually don’t even need to modify code between our two-swerve practice bot and our normal bot. I wouldn’t pitch this for a competition bot, but for a practice testbench? Absolutely.

evanperryg:

If your center of gravity isn’t perfectly centered over the middle of the robot, you will never, ever drive straight unless you do weird stuff in your code to compensate.

Actually even more generally, mecanum drives rarely drive straight even if the CG is centered and your frame is built to good tolerances unless you solve a rather complicated controls problem. The easiest way to demonstrate it is to drive a mecanum drive bot forwards, than suddenly sideways. Two of the wheels need to swap directions, but because the wheels and robot has inertia and non-zero latency, the robot skews and you aren’t straight anymore. This isn’t unsolvabe, but it is outside the means of almost every FRC team to solve, hence why most mecanum FRC and FTC bots don’t drive straight to some degree or another unless driven slowly.

It is possible to solve this problem (I’ve personally done so), its really hard (you need to use a cartesion-space inverse dynamics controller, while extrapolating out latency and avoiding voltage, current, and traction saturations), while swerve is just less susceptible to these issues due to having more traction and throwing 400W brushless motors at the problem.

I would not recommend mechanum if you are looking to be a more competitive robot. While it’s used for ftc robots, mechanum allows your robot to be more easily pushed around. There was only one robot at one of our comps this year that had mechanum, and it was constantly being pushed around by defending robots or the bots it was trying to defend, leading it to be put on our no-pick list

posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked:
I’m not trying to dissuade you from a learning opportunity. However our team has run mecanum once. We only used it in 2021 which was covid year. No defense, but it was flashy for a team that couldn’t run swerve.

I would highly recommend trying out swerve if you can pull together the funds. There are a lot of great tools out there. For coding there is YAGSL . There are great widening guides and SDS is very straightforward mechanically. (Don’t put magnets upsidown)

However it is expensive and our team is lucky to have generous sponsors. I would recommend looking for a grant from a sponsor specifically for a swerve base. If they see the innovation and STEM behind what they are supporting it will help you get the funds.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
four:

Driver practice will be far more impactful in terms of performance than any drivetrain. If your driver can reach peak efficiency with your current drivetrain, you will do well

Drive practice is critically important AND swerve gives you two big advantages towards this goal.

(1) Building a swerve drive base is dead easy.  Cut 4 2x1 tubes to the appropriate lengths, bolt on your modules and cut a quick and dirty belly pan out of 5mm plywood. Attach your electronics.  Once you decide on a robot size, you should be up and practicing driving in a day or two.

(2) Swerve gets you “field oriented” (as opposed to “robot oriented”) controls.  This makes driving sooooo much easier.

This was how we did our “first”{1} swerve, (which we called “Barbie Bot”).

IMG_0010 3024×4032 2.78 MB IMG_0381 4032×3024 4.76 MB

IMG_0381 4032×3024 4.76 MB

.
